I have some general thoughts on timeout handling...

What we want:
* Initiate a connection to the action container's listening socket and send a POST to `/init` / `/run` endpoints.
* Once we successfully sent the POST request, we want to receive the response within the action timeout. If the response does not arrive within the timeout, we want to receive a unique exception. I'm not sure which exact exception is thrown in this case.
   This timeout is likely set by [RequestConfig.Builder.setSocketTimeout()](https://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-client-ga/httpclient/apidocs/org/apache/http/client/config/RequestConfig.Builder.html#setSocketTimeout(int)).
* Once we successfully sent the POST request, no more retries are desired because POST requests are not idempotent.
* We only want retries for failures where we are sure that the target action container has not yet received any POST requests - probably not even fragments of a request.
* Establishing the TCP connection may take some seconds. These are reasons why the connection cannot be established immediately:
  * The action container is not yet running (`HttpHostConnectException` on Linux?).
  * The action container is running but the system's routing table does not yet have a route to the action container's network interface (`NoRouteToHostException`).
  * The action container is not yet listening (`HttpHostConnectException` on Linux?).
* We want some retries for transient TCP connection initiation problems - but not wait longer than 10 seconds in total for a managed container. Maybe longer for a blackbox container.
   We definitely do NOT want to wait as long as the action timeout here.
* If the action container has stopped running, there is not point in waiting because it's not a transient problem. This is what @markusthoemmes brought up.

What we have at the moment:
* We set very long timeout values for initiating the TCP connection and obtaining a connection from the connection manager. We allow the full action timeout which does not make sense from my point of view. Does anybody know why we set it this way?
* We do not consider the time spent in executing the HTTP request for determining whether we still retry. @dubee found this and this PR irons out this flaw.

IMHO with regard to the admin API, I have been requested from users that they want to see the real-time status of their invocation.
For example, one of my users invokes an action with 200 ~ 300 concurrent containers for about 4 ~ 5 mins. In this case, he cannot call it with blocking call, he calls them asynchronously.
And at some point, he wants to make sure all his concurrent invocation finished.
Currently, he needs to indirectly poll activation and count the number of finished invocation.

I think we need to track the invocation status for each users in the future.(Though there could be some differences because invocation duration can be short.)
It can be achieved with controller API as well, but invoker-side API would give us more fine-grained control as containers are actually running on the invoker side.

One more point is what @ningyougang said.
In the future, there will be some needs for different kinds of container pool.
For example, users might need GPU enabled host, and users might expect more powerful hosts or dedicated resources with higher prices. Or OW operator(public cloud) might want to deploy invoker in many different types of host machines to maximize the utilization of computing resources in the cloud. And the heterogenous invoker cluster requires heterogenous prewarm configuration for efficiency and flexbility. 
This is why I think the API should exist in each invoker and it is same for controllers as well.

And one of my collegues who is public cloud operator said, he noticed that invocation pattern of each runtimes changes over time. For example, python actions mostly invoked during the morning, PHP actions are invoked during the evening and so on. Also invocation patterns change based on the social events such as big conferences, world cup, big news and so on. He is thinking of dynamically changing the prewarm configuration based on the request pattern prediction with machine learning to minimize cold start. I think this feature can be provided outside of OW and per-invoker or per-controller API would be a good building block for this.
